target_title: Unlink animation speed from gesture proceeding speed.

note.body:
I think that problem @paradigma1337 is experiencing is a bug in an external extension (in combination with GNOME 47).

It is extension with rather long name **AppIndicator and KStatusNotifierItem Support** that is causing the weird animation stutters when lifting the fingers in a gesture. We can clearly see the icons on the system tray in the example recording, suggesting that indeed @paradigma1337 is using some kind of extension for this (and so did I).

Link to extension: [https://extensions.gnome.org/extension/615/appindicator-support/](https://extensions.gnome.org/extension/615/appindicator-support/)

See below an example recording with the extension **ON**.

> First two gestures are done without lifting the fingers, rest is done with lifting them.

![Screencast_From_2024-12-31_13-20-23](/uploads/d01b92fb228ee87ffd5e13d9d511525d/Screencast_From_2024-12-31_13-20-23.mp4)

And an example recording with the extension **OFF**.

![Screencast_From_2024-12-31_13-50-02](/uploads/1ba65d783e381bbc0e8d65262852e1d7/Screencast_From_2024-12-31_13-50-02.mp4)

Without it all animations and gestures seem to work smoothly.

I would suggest disabling this extension and report back if the issue prevails.

note.body:
> I also get the sense that "copy to the clipboard" was particularly used in combination with area capture - it made sense as a quick way to grab part of the screen and paste it somewhere.

Not always though. There isn't a single assumption you can make that will always be correct. What I want from this feature is to save me the busywork of having to go every week and clear (a few times hundreds of) junk screenshots from my screenshots folder and only keep the few I know I want, when a toggle or a shortcut or a modifier key would have prevented this because _I_ know at the time of taking the screenshot that I will only use it once.

> Given these factors, I don't think that a persistent "save to file" toggle is going to cut it.

Could you explain your thought process for this? From the responses I see and my experience it seems like it would be okay.
Either way, thinking of alternatives, would making Ctrl-C only copy and a text hint at the bottom of the screenshot UI advertising the shortcut be enough? The current Ctrl-C behaviour is already broken anyway considering no other GNOME or non-GNOME app uses Ctrl-C to save a file to a disk, that always means copy to clipboard, see also: #8128

note.body:
I think the `-Werror` is there to trigger an error rather than warning when the compiler detects an invalid format string, i.e. when there is no support for the `I` modifier so meson is able to detect that.

Maybe the check in gjs can be changed to a simple version check or just a check for glibc. glibc 2.2 which introduced support for this was released over 20 years ago. As far as I can tell musl does not support this.

Alternatively the `-Werror` could be restricted to format errors by using `-Werror=format` instead. That doesn't seem to work for clang, but neither does the current code.

note.body:
Yep, we have a `NO` here on Arch as well

```
Checking if "printf() supports %I alternative int syntax" compiles: NO
```

On the build system environment it's like this:

```Code:

#include <stdio.h>
int main(void) {
    printf("%Id", (int)0);
    return 0;
}

-----------
Command line: `cc /build/gjs/src/build/meson-private/tmphfs29q22/testfile.c -o /build/gjs/src/build/meson-private/tmphfs29q22/output.obj -c -march=x86-64 -mtune=generic -O2 -pipe -fno-plt -fexceptions -Wp,-D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=3 -Wformat -Werror=format-security -fstack-clash-protection -fcf-protection -fno-omit-frame-pointer -mno-omit-leaf-frame-pointer -g -ffile-prefix-map=/build/gjs/src=/usr/src/debug/gjs -flto=auto -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64 -O0 -std=c99 -Werror -Wformat` -> 1
stderr:
In file included from /usr/include/bits/libc-header-start.h:33,
                 from /usr/include/stdio.h:28,
                 from /build/gjs/src/build/meson-private/tmphfs29q22/testfile.c:2:
/usr/include/features.h:422:4: error: #warning _FORTIFY_SOURCE requires compiling with optimization (-O) [-Werror=cpp]
  422 | #  warning _FORTIFY_SOURCE requires compiling with optimization (-O)
      |    ^~~~~~~
cc1: all warnings being treated as errors
```

So this might be because of the `-Werror` or the `-O0` (on which I'm not sure where this comes from)

-------
EDIT: I can confirm, if I patch the [meson.build](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gjs/-/blob/master/meson.build?ref_type=heads#L293) to

        args: ['-Werror','-O2', '-Wformat'],

It have the desired `Checking if "printf() supports %I alternative int syntax" compiles: YES` of course thats a dirty workaround and nothing I want to add.

note.body:
I just checked and it is working correctly here on my jhbuild session. The Persian translation correctly uses `%Id` for these values and gnome-shell uses the `format()` method provided by `gjs` which just forwards this to glib, but only if `gjs` was compiled on a system with alternative output digits support in glibc.

![screenshot](/uploads/f8a341718f29ce674c65b80956fd8bc1/screenshot.png)


The gjs I built in jhbuild shows this at build time:

```
Checking if "printf() supports %I alternative int syntax" compiles: YES 
```

I then tested this with the default Fedora 41 packages and there it does not work. There I see the following in the `gjs` package [build logs](https://kojipkgs.fedoraproject.org//packages/gjs/1.82.1/3.fc41/data/logs/x86_64/build.log):

```
Checking if "printf() supports %I alternative int syntax" compiles: NO 
```

This means that `gjs` from the Fedora package won't forward the `%Id` to glib but instead just use `%d`. Maybe there is some missing build time dependency for the `gjs` package that is required for alternative output digit support in glibc.


So I would suspect that this could be caused by a similar gjs build issue on Arch as well. When the `gjs` package for Arch was compiled, what did it say for "printf() supports %I alternative int syntax"? I can't find the build logs of Arch packages.

note.body:
> The timestamps are stored in the file to second precision.

Not rounded though? They still contain microsecond precision for me.
[session-active-history.json](/uploads/8334c2a5aac02d972ce174ad94bfc64e/session-active-history.json) (That's an invalid JSON according to Settings by the way, but the timestamps are never equal)

target_title: timeLimitsManager: Add new state machine for screen time limits

note.body:
The timestamps are stored in the file to second precision. It’s an invalid file because that’s how I’ve defined the file format, precisely to avoid having to deal with doubles.

I have a fix in mind for the shell which would filter out consecutive pairs of entries which have the same timestamp and whose state changes cancel each other out.

target_title: timeLimitsManager: Add new state machine for screen time limits

note.body:
Hmm, considering the timestamps in the json aren't equal in their full microsecond precision (only when truncated to integer seconds), I don't really see why this is an invalid file? And how would Shell solve this, unless you would do some rate limiting to the updates?

It's just that the Settings impl takes the (double precision, derived from microsecond) timestamps and truncates them to integer seconds. Under that assumption you can indeed interpret the file invalid, but the consequent full precision timestamp values in my testing are still never equal and always increasing (i.e. "valid" in my interpretation).

I would see this more as an interpretation difference of what constitutes a valid file and with what precision that should hold, which can also be solved from the Settings side.

I repeat the steps, since the original post is no more readable (at least for me).

_Edit: Actually, it is still available, but the rendering of [the post](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/-/issues/3867#note_1056590) made me think, that it has been altered._


```shell
# 1. Setup the expected display configuration for your login screen in your session (graphical step)
# I personally mirror all screens

# 2. Copy your display configuration file to the gdm3 user
sudo cp ~/.config/monitors.xml /var/lib/gdm3/.config/monitors.xml

# 3. Ensure the file has the correct ownership
sudo chown :gdm /var/lib/gdm3/.config/monitors.xml

# 4. Restore your original display configuration for your session (once again graphical)

# 5. Restart and pray (if not working, try praying first, then restart)
```

target_title: dbus: Add internal API suitable for GlobalShortcuts

note.body:
If I read this correctly, then the `groupId` is not bound in any way to the `sender`. That is, any sender can replace the `group` for some other process behind its back, as long as it knows the group name. That's quite unexpected I think (and also bears the question what use is for tracking the sender here).

I wonder whether it would be better to store accelerators in `this._acceleratorGroups` as `Map(sender → Map(group → shortcuts))`.

target_title: timeLimitsManager: Add new state machine for screen time limits

note.body:
Mmh, this doesn't look like it would work, at least not reliably.

The `shutdown` signal is emitted after the main loop returned, just before tearing down. There is nothing that delays the tear down until any async operations started from a signal handler is completed. There are cases where that's fine, like fire-and-forget D-Bus calls, but not for file operations.

apps launched from gnome-shell on Wayland sometimes inherit higher soft limit for open file descriptors

note.body:
> Ideally with a simple program like `xterm` as the app that is being launched, rather than something as complicated as a Flatpak app?

1. Override the XTerm desktop file

    ```bash
    cp /usr/share/applications/debian-xterm.desktop .
    cat << EOF >> debian-xterm.desktop
    Actions=new-window

    [Desktop Action new-window]
    Name=Custom New Window
    Exec=xterm
    EOF
    mv debian-xterm.desktop ~/.local/share/applications/
    ```
2. Find XTerm from Gnome Activities
3. Right click on XTerm to verify that the actions list contains "Custom New Window" instead of "New Window"
4. Start XTerm by either launching from the icon or directly from the "Custom New Window" action
5. Run `prlimit -n` in XTerm and it should show a soft limit of `1073741816`

Basically all Desktop Actions get launched via `shell_app_launch_action` and the apps are spawned directly if the actions are not registered on session bus. When launching an app by left clicking, the nofile rlimit will not be restored if the app has a "new-window" action. It also will not be restored if any other Desktop Action is used from the app's right click menu.

It is actually quite annoying with flatpak apps, since most of them use Desktop Actions in the .desktop files (e.g. Chromium, Brave, Firefox, Thunderbird, Libreoffice) for sandboxing reasons. Any launch action takes then about a minute to complete while flatpak loops through the fds. This essentially hinders the usability of the dock on any distro having a combination of gnome, wayland, flatpak (<1.15.x) and dash-to-dock/ubuntu-dock or similar (e.g. Ubuntu 24.10).

Creating an additional dbus service for launching apps sounds like a lot of work, although it would be nice to have an ability to customize desktop app limits in systemd. A lighter option could be to split `g_desktop_app_info_launch_action` in glib to two additional functions: `g_desktop_app_info_launch_action_with_spawn` and `g_desktop_app_info_launch_action_with_dbus`. The implementation would then match `g_desktop_app_info_launch_uris` and wouldn't break the ABI. Another option could be to implement the launch action handling directly in `shell-app.c`, but that would mean some duplicate code with glib.

note.body: Yes and no. This `g_warning()` is pretty standard with `GSource` implementations. I’ve never thought about why before — and you’re right to suggest that a callback should be provided in the constructor if only `g_source_set_callback()` were to be called. However, I think it’s necessary because a `GSource` callback can be provided in a lot of ways: `g_source_set_callback()`, `g_source_set_closure()`, `g_source_set_callback_indirect()`, `g_source_set_dummy_callback()`. So the constructor would have to support all of those, or the caller would have to pass some dummy data into the constructor and then call a different callback setter if they wanted to use a different one.

target_title: Gnome 47 is not respecting scaling on external monitor
Spotlight effect only uses 8bit alpha depth due to offscreen

note.body:
Exactly, hence the dithering is always needed. (Even with floating-point scanout formats, there are still accuracy limits in the display link and monitor)

An exacerbating factor is that the i915 kernel driver doesn't seem to do any display dithering if the display link & monitor support at least 8 bpc, which is exactly the case with the setup where I saw banding. So even though mutter uses a 10 bpc scanout format, the monitor effectively shows only 8 bpc. That's one reason why the magnitude of the dithering noise in the final output must be at least 1/255.

target_title: Spotlight effect only uses 8bit alpha depth due to offscreen

note.body: I suppose 10-bit could have banding too. That's the problem with shadows and darkening; you run out of unique colour values compared to the original undarkened image.

target_title: Spotlight effect only uses 8bit alpha depth due to offscreen

note.body: Step 1: Check your monitor can do 10-bit gradients without banding. It doesn't need to have a full 10-bit panel, just to have effective FRC (temporal dithering).

target_title: status/a11y: Block 'toggled' signal when manually toggling

note.body:
I think the pattern of storing bits on the wrapper object[^0] is something we should avoid.

[^0]: "wrapper object" is the javascript object that gjs creates to expose the C GObject to javascript

I remember that gjs stopped keeping the wrapper object alive for the entire lifetime of the underlying object, and we were running into issues when any monkey-patched properties on the wrapper were lost. It's possible that this was addressed on the gjs side, but then we'd still block an (otherwise) unnecessary wrapper object from being released.

I opened !3576 earlier, after which `_buildItemExtended()` is only called by `_buildFontItem()`. That is, the two could be merged, and then this patch could do one of
```js
    const toggledId = widget.connect('toggled', ...)
```
or
```js
    this._fontItemToggledId = widget.connect('toggled', ...)
```
which both avoid monkey-patching the wrapper.

Does this sound reasonable to you?

target_title: Touchscreen only devices : gnome activities overview do not provide a way to close windows
Touchscreen only device: gnome activities closing window is not user friendly
Touchscreen only devices : gnome activities overview do not provide a way to close windows

note.body:
@fmuellner This is not a viable solution and not userfriendly because of following reasons:
1. pressing not long enough: the overview closes and opens pressed window.
2. moving the finger very slightly: the window in overview gets dragged.
3. the hover deactivates after 1 second again, which is an unreasonable short time to press such a small button precisely.
4. many users will not know about it, without looking it up in the internet, because it is not an intuitive design.

what would improve this:
1. close the window by draging it into empty space somewhere on the overview
2. close the window by draging it into a trash bin. this trash bin only shows up if a window is dragged.
3. close the window by swiping up on it with a touch screen, like it works on most modern phones.
4. remove the timer on the hover gesture and only close it if another window is hovered over. then the user has at least enough time to press the x-button.

Bonus points if users would be able to decide which function they want to use in the setting-menu. Option 3 is the preferred solutions for myself. Option 4 is only a band-aid on the current system.

For context, I was showing a non-tech-savvy person around GNOME and overall they found all the interactions very natural except they kept gesturing the wrong way within the overview and thinking it wasn't working (because there's no overscroll indication, they thought that their gesture just wasn't working even though it was actually because they were doing it in the wrong direction).

target_title: lightbox: Use variable magnitude for dithering noise

note.body:
The effect would create solid black with alpha 1.0, i.e. it doesn't make sense.

It's not possible in practice ATM, `cogl_color_out.a *= 1.0 - pixel_brightness * brightness` can never become 1.0, since `brightness` varies between 0.5 - 1.0 and `pixel_brightness` between 0.3 - 1.0. While that could change in the future in theory, it wouldn't make sense per above.

```
object:state-changed:focused from window Main stage of application gnome-shell

Detail1: 1, Detail2: 0

Detail1: 1, Detail2: 0
window:activate from window Main stage of application gnome-shell
Detail1: 0, Detail2: 0

Detail1: 1, Detail2: 0

```
So, at the end, the focus event from the text field comes, but before it there's a lot of junk, which causes Orca to announce the main stage as weel.

note.body:
Debian Unstable using GNOME Shell 47.2, 

Finally managed to reproduce it in the newer version of GNOME. 

1. I created a `custom-browser.desktop` file 

```
[Desktop Entry]
Name=Custom Browser
Comment=Custom Browser
GenericName=Custom Browser
X-GNOME-FullName=Custom Browser
Exec=/home/daitj/.local/bin/custom-browser %u
Terminal=false
X-MultipleArgs=false
Type=Application
Icon=firefox-esr
Categories=Network;WebBrowser;
StartupWMClass=custom-browser
StartupNotify=true
Name[en_US]=Custom Browser
MimeType=x-scheme-handler/unknown;x-scheme-handler/about;text/html;text/xml;application/xhtml+xml;application/xml;application/vnd.mozilla.xul+xml;application/rss+xml;application/rdf+xml;image/gif;image/jpeg;image/png;x-scheme-handler/http;x-scheme-handler/https;
``` 

2. Content of `/home/daitj/.local/bin/custom-browser`
```
#!/bin/bash
/usr/bin/xterm
```

3. Then I registered that `Custom Browser` as my default browser
```
xdg-settings set default-web-browser custom-browser.desktop
```

4. I created an empty new gnome extension and added following line in the enable() function
```
Gio.AppInfo.launch_default_for_uri("https://example.com", null);
```
`metadata.json`
```
{
  "description": "Test extension to launch xterm",
  "name": "Launch xterm",
  "shell-version": [
    "46",
    "47"
  ],
  "url": "https://example.com",
  "uuid": "xterm-launcher@daitj",
  "version": 1
}
```
`extension.js`
```
import Gio from 'gi://Gio';

export default class XtermLauncherClass {
    constructor() {
    }
    enable() {
        Gio.AppInfo.launch_default_for_uri("https://example.com", null);
    }
    disable() {
    }
}
```

5. Logout and Login, xterm launches , you can also disable and enable extension to launch xterm again. 

6. In this launched xterm and I could run following command, where soft = 1073741816
```
cat /proc/$(pgrep xterm | tail -n1)/limits
```

target_title: apps launched from gnome-shell on Wayland sometimes inherit higher soft limit for open file descriptors

note.body:
> Maybe we could fork, reset the limit, activate the action and exit?

In a multi-threaded process, the only thing you can safely do after `fork()` but before `execve()` is to call async-signal-safe functions, and that excludes dynamic memory allocation and the vast majority of GLib (`GDesktopAppInfo` certainly isn't designed to be async-signal-safe). So I think unfortunately it would have to be in a helper that is a separate executable (or in some sort of D-Bus service, or something).

> I assume that `xterm` is case number 3, while `firefox` is 1

"Native" `firefox-esr` in Debian is actually case 3: its .desktop file doesn't implement Desktop Actions.

But the Flatpak Firefox app is indeed case 1: it has `[Desktop Action new-window]` in `/var/lib/flatpak/exports/share/applications/org.mozilla.firefox.desktop`.

(@daitj, as a note for the future: if you're reporting a bug that involves a specific application, it would be useful to say where you got that application from and what version it is!)

From what @daitj said in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/-/issues/7958#note_2296511, it seems like this particular case was wrong in 47.0-2, but has been fixed in 47.2-2. Does that seem plausible?

target_title: apps launched from gnome-shell on Wayland sometimes inherit higher soft limit for open file descriptors

note.body:
> But I cannot reproduce this myself by using a simple `xterm`

Ah yes, "open window" can behave quite differently under the hood. There are three cases:

1. there's a `new-window` action in the .desktop file
2. the app is running, and exported a `new-window` action over D-Bus
3. none of the above, just launch the app again (and hope that it'll actually open a new window)

I assume that `xterm` is case number 3, while `firefox` is 1. And indeed, that's results in a call to `g_desktop_app_info_launch_action()`, which doesn't have a "child-setup" hook that would allow us to reset the limit.

note.body:
Short update: As of Mesa 23.4.1, Linux 6.11.11 and Gst `main` from today I unfortunately still experience GPU crashe with `vaav1enc` on the one system I have for testing. And because we still don't support GL robustness in Mutter this makes the session crash. I haven't debugged this further yet.

Regarding the file sizes: the `va*enc` elements, like the sw elements, support quantizer options that we should be able to tune to some reasonable number - notably making the resulting files small enough for web upload and not filling up harddrives too fast while maintaining reasonable quality. This should just need some testing - and should probably also be applied to the existing `vah264enc` pipeline.

target_title: apps launched from gnome-shell on Wayland sometimes inherit higher soft limit for open file descriptors

note.body:
In Flatpak 1.14.x, apps will be very slow to start if the soft fd limit is very large (because Flatpak only learned to use `close_range()` in the 1.15.x development branch); so the issue reporter's "very slow" would seem to imply that apps launched from the Overview search have the intended soft limit, typically 1024, but "Open new window" from the dock might result in a second copy of Firefox being launched, with an unintended higher soft limit.

So I think the steps to reproduce might be something like this:

1. Launch an app from the Overview search, preferably choosing an app that is not going to alter its own rlimits. I tried to reproduce this with `xterm`.
2. `prlimit -p $(pgrep xterm|tail -n1)|grep NOFILE` → soft = 1024, hard ≈ 1e9 as expected
3. Right-click on the app's icon in the Dock; Open new window
4. `prlimit -p $(pgrep xterm|tail -n1)|grep NOFILE` (use the new instance's pid this time)
5. Expected result: soft = 1024, hard ≈ 1e9
6. Actual result that the issue reporter observes: soft ≈ 1e9, hard ≈ 1e9

But I cannot reproduce this myself by using a simple `xterm` (in gnome-shell 47.2-1 and mutter 47.3-2, both from Debian unstable): I get the expected result. So there must be something more to this.

target_title: apps launched from gnome-shell on Wayland sometimes inherit higher soft limit for open file descriptors

note.body:
The issue reporter wrote:

> So on normal (first) launch from search of Firefox, it launches immediately but if I right click on already launched Firefox icon from the dock in the bottom and press on "Open new window" it is very slow.

From their mention of `bwrap` and what has been said on other issue reports, I infer that their copy of Firefox might be a Flatpak app.

Unlink animation speed from gesture proceeding speed.

note.body:
This would be pretty much the opposite of the current design, so this would need some feedback from the design team.

Also the animation already becomes independent of the gesture speed as soon as you lift your fingers from the touchpad. If you performed a long and fast enough swipe, the animation will trigger and be independent on the gesture speed. So the only case where the suggested change would have an impact would be when slowly performing the gesture while keeping the fingers on the touchpad. I think triggering a faster animation that is independent of what the fingers are doing on the touchpad would feel disconnected rather than smooth.

note.body:
> 5. Loading indicator appears underneath system clock, with a notice of what it is doing at the moment, or just a generic "switching out..." message.
> 6. Login screen is loaded in the background, move lock screen away (perhaps back upwards, as to make them feel like a curtain unveiling the new stage behind it)

Switching users involves a VT switch and starting up a separate session under a different user (usually "gdm"). Starting an animation in one session, keeping it running smoothly during the switch and finishing it in a separate session is not possible.

It's certainly possible to do a bit better, but an actionable design must take technical constraints into accounts.

target_title: GNOME-Shell often crashes when fullscreen application happens (Firefox video or screen lock even)

note.body:
That sounds like a different bug and can be caused by any required component of a gnome-session crashing (and failing to restart), not just gnome-shell. You'd have to check the logs to see what is crashing.

I'm pretty the fullscreen crash referred to in the original issue was a duplicate of https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/-/issues/3450, which was Wayland specific and has been fixed in 47.2. That matches the situations in which it was happening and the lack of a backtrace due to the gnome-shell process getting killed rather than crashing. Unfortunately we never received a reply to fully confirm this.

The crash originally reported here related to the lock screen is yet another bug. In this case a duplicate of https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/-/issues/7339. If that was the source of your crash I would expect gnome-shell to be able to restart, which should not result in gnome-session triggering the error screen. So your issue is probably different from both issues included in the original report.

Since we haven't received any replies from the original reporter and the issues are already solved or tracked elsewhere and the title of this issue seems to be attracting more reports of most likely unrelated issues it's probably best to close this.

If the crash you are running into is a gnome-shell one, please open a new issue with a backtrace of the crash.

note.body:
Trying to use the whole thing again I noticed a few issues:

1. create-toolbox.sh is not idempotent: if an error occurs (e.g. when installing mutter) it won't run to completion and running it again just detects that the toolbox exists and exits.
2. sysext-update.sh does output a bunch of warnings when compiling the schema which isn't useful
3. sysext-update.sh does not indicate if the extension is installed and/or active at the end. Especially a OS version mismatch can be confusing because the extension won't load without indication.

target_title: toolbox: Add tooling for exporting system extension from container

note.body:
> all of the script is supposed to run privileged.

Not all of it. Getting the extension files out of the toolbox is done as user, and that bit would be trickier when done as root (you'll have to figure out the "real" user and their XDG_DATA_HOME to point to the correct container storage).

The script is also careful to not create any privileged files in $HOME, so the user can clean up `~/.local/lib/toolbox-extensions` without gaining root.

target_title: RFE: detect captive portals and do the right thing

note.body:
Exactly.

When a WiFi connection requires a captive portal confirmation, GNOME **currently** shows only a single notification that has to be clicked by the user to open the captive portal website.

If the notification is gone, there is currently no way for the user to reopen the captive portal page.

What GNOME **should** do is the same what Android is doing: provide the user an option to open the captive portal page **until** the Internet connection works.

target_title: windowPreview: Adjust WindowPreview stack when stackAbove overlay shown

note.body:
I was busying working on my thesis so I barely had time working on this until this weekend... After reading code (again), I decided to modify this patch to try fixing things inside `_restack()` instead of calling `_restack()` frequently.

Call `this.hideOverlay()` immediately in `vfunc_leave_event` like `this.showOverlay()` in `vfunc_enter_event` does not work nicely, as this changes UX, and moving pointer to close button/icon/title also triggers `vfunc_leave_event`.

It's also not easy to add things like `this._stackBelow`. Implementing it would increase the complexity of the `WindowPreview` code, and, at the moment, I don't have the time or energy to invest in such an effort.

So here I take the relatively easy approach to resolve this glitch. Though due to the delayed run (750ms) of `hideOverlay` in `vfunc_leave_event`, there could be several WindowPreview in stack with `_overlayShown`, and I'm not sure how to handle this, my local test shows that it seems working well.

note.body:
The code path for the in app search in nautilus is not exactly the same as the one used for the search provider. Also there is no further filtering on the shell side other than limiting the number of displayed results from a search provider to 5. Problems like this are usually on the search provider side.

If you want to confirm whether this happens on the nautilus or shell side, you can use `dbus-monitor 'type=method_call' 'type=method_return'` to check if gnome-shell is sending the right method call to the nautilus search provider and if the nautilus search provider is returning results that are maybe not shown by gnome-shell. In the output search for method calls to `path=/org/gnome/Nautilus/SearchProvider` and then look for the corresponding method return where the `reply_serial` matches the `serial` of the method call.

target_title: The Lock signal is not emitted by systemd-logind when the screen is locked

note.body:
> According to the systemd-logind documentation the **Lock signal** will be sent to D-Bus by systemd-logind when the screen is locked. This does not happen when the lock screen is activated.

From [the documentation](https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/latest/org.freedesktop.login1.html) I do not come to the same conclusion as to the cause and effect of the Lock signal, though I can see the ambiguity.

## The relevant sections in the systemd-login documentation

### `Session.Lock()` and `Session.Unlock` method
>  `Lock()`, `Unlock()`, `Kill()` work similar to the respective calls on the Manager object.

### `Manager.LockSession()` and `Manager.UnlockSession()`
> `LockSession()` asks the session with the specified ID to activate the screen lock. `UnlockSession()` asks the session with the specified ID to remove an active screen lock, if there is any. This is implemented by sending out the `Lock()` and `Unlock()` signals from the respective session object which session managers are supposed to listen on.

### `Session.Lock` and `Session.Unlock` signal
> `Lock()/Unlock()` is sent when the session is asked to be screen-locked/unlocked. A session manager of the session should listen to this signal and act accordingly. This signal is sent out as a result of the `Lock()` and `Unlock()` methods, respectively.

## What this means for a fully compliant implementation

1. The user presses the button to lock the screen, `Session.Lock()` method should be called.
2. This causes the `Session.Lock` signal to be sent, Gnome shell should listen for this signal and show the lock screen.
   Notice that the signal triggers the lockscreen and not the other way around.
3. Gnome shell now calls `Session.SetLockedHint(true)`.
4. Now, two things can happen:
   - Gnome shell receives `Session.Unlock` signal, it should now remove the lockscreen.
   - The user enters their credentials and unlocks the lockscreen.
5. Gnome Shell must now call `Session.SetLockedHint(false)`.

Step one and two might look a bit superfluous because it is basically Gnome talking to itself to lock via D-Bus. This does make sense in case of non-tightly integrated systems where one component might ask for a lock but does not implement this functionality itself.

## Supporting evidence
When executing `loginctl lock-session`, without any DE or lockscreen program, the following events can be observed on the system bus:
```
‣ Type=method_call  Endian=l  Flags=4  Version=1 Cookie=2  Timestamp="Sat 2024-11-30 21:33:26.500598 UTC"
  Sender=:1.1353  Destination=org.freedesktop.login1  Path=/org/freedesktop/login1/session/auto  Interface=org.freedesktop.login1.Session  Member=Lock
  UniqueName=:1.1353
  MESSAGE "" {
  };
‣ Type=signal  Endian=l  Flags=1  Version=1 Cookie=846  Timestamp="Sat 2024-11-30 21:33:26.500776 UTC"
  Sender=:1.6  Path=/org/freedesktop/login1/session/_33  Interface=org.freedesktop.login1.Session  Member=Lock
  UniqueName=:1.6
  MESSAGE "" {
  };
```
This shows that `org.freedesktop.login1.Session.Lock` signal is used to ask for a lockscreen rather than confirm a lockscreen is present.

## In conclusion
The `Lock` signal should not be seen as "the session is now locked", but rather, "please lock the session whoever can do this". In addition, the signal could be ignored or inhibited so it cannot be seen as a confirmation that a lockscreen is indeed present, that is what `LockedHint` is for. This means that applications such as notification emitters that want to show a message or play a sound but not do so when the screen is locked, should do so based on `LockedHint`.

target_title: Gnome shell crashing when unlocking the screen

note.body:
Ok, that's it, using the OSK gives me a reliable reproducer (and it's likely also what happened when I first encountered the issue: This is a Thinkpad X13 Yoga, but I've not been using it much in tablet mode. However, a few days ago I did to test something.)

What I did is roughly:
- log in with gdm
- fold laptop to enter tablet mode
- open shell overview, focus search and open osk, enter a few characters
- close overview
- fold back to laptop mode
- connect external screen
- close laptop lid
- continue using the laptop for a bit (open/close applications, open/close shell overview, open/close lid)

This did not immediately trigger the use-after-free/crash, but a little later (less than 1min I would guess) either Valgrind errors start showing up or the shell will segfault.

target_title: toolbox: Add tooling for exporting system extension from container

note.body:
> Could we not add sysext-utils to the toolbox image and call that instead of the custom bash script?

I went back to that today, and I'd say: not really.

It's possible to
 - add sysext-utils and squashfs-tools to the toolbox
 - use sysext-build to create a raw image from the directory tree inside the toolbox
 - do the custom schema-compile + install sysext image implementation in the script

Replacing the last step with sysext-add would be the main selling point - it's where most of the magic happens, i.e. schema/icon handling; unfortunately that doesn't work inside the toolbox, because it needs real root.

That is, we can basically replace "podman cp" with "sysext-build", but nothing more. I don't think that's worth it.

breakManager: Add new state machine for screen time/health breaks

note.body:
As I previously said in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/-/merge_requests/3251#note_2173557, the state/logic from `BreakNotificationSource` can’t be in `BreakNotification` because `BreakNotification` gets destroyed whenever the user closes it, which would lose the state (such as the timer for when to next update the notification content).

It could all be moved into `BreakDispatcher`, but then that class becomes a lot more complex, and dominated by code for notification management — when the whole point of `BreakDispatcher` is to support multiple types of UI interaction (not just notifications).

target_title: breakManager: Add new state machine for screen time/health breaks

note.body:
I see what you mean, and I agree that makes a lot of sense if the destroy code path is only used on shutdown. However, the code in this file does things like calling `this.destroy()` in a few places as a way to deinitialise resources when break reminders are disabled at runtime. In that case, we want things like `this._manager` to be `null` and gracefully handle it, rather than having everything undefined.

For example, the `BreakState` can switch between `DISABLED` and other states during the gnome-shell process’ lifetime.

I could factor out a separate ‘disable’ function if you want, but it would look exactly like `_onDestroy()` except with `delete` rather than `blah = null`. The two would have to be kept in sync, which imo is easy to forget to do, which is why I decided to structure it this way.

note.body:
I think most of the logic in `BreakNotificationSource` should be moved to `BreakNotification`, since the notification has access to information via the `BreakManager` anyway, and it makes it easier to figure out the content of the notification. Also, I don't think that `BreakNotificationSource` should store the same state as the `BreakDispatcher`. And the `BreakDispatcher` should create the `Source` and `Notification` when need based the current state in `BreakDispatcher`.

As a side effect, this removes the need of the `allow-empty` property.

note.body:
These days I prefer to `delete this._foo` on destructors, so that the JavaScript object is cleaned up. This also allows knowing when code accidentally ran after destruction.

So basically, while code is supposed to be running, these fields are either `null` or some valid object. After destruction, they're deleted, thus becoming `undefined`.

target_title: Bump version to 46.7
Non-square album covers are stretched in the MPRIS notification

note.body:
That's correct, but unfortunately the issue goes deeper and will require a fair bit of yak shaving.

MPRIS messages share a common base with notifications, and use its `icon` property for cover art. Icons (in notifications and elsewhere) are represented by an `St.Icon`, which very specifically targets the icon use case (may be themed, symbolic, ..., but always: square).

For non-icon images, we'd need something like `St.Picture` (loosely modeled after the [Gtk.Picture API](https://docs.gtk.org/gtk4/class.Picture.html)), support it in `MessageList.Message`, and then finally use it in `Mpris.MediaMessage`.

Add uninstall hook for extensions
Add uninstall hook for extensions

note.body:
What exactly is the use case for "files associated with an extension, which should be kept around even when the extension is disabled, but removed when it is uninstalled"?

The whole thing sounds extremely dodgy to me to be honest. I can see why you wouldn't want to delete a bunch of stuff when the extension is temporarily being disabled (like on screen lock), but leaving stuff around (in particular if it's user-visible, like .desktop files may be) after the user disables the extension feels quite wrong.

It doesn't help that the patch in its current form is problematic in various ways:
 - the `uninstall()` hook can be used as "prevent uninstallation" hook (by throwing an error)
 - the hook is assumed to be present, which will fail for all extensions that don't subclass the Extension convenience class (and don't implement the hook themselves)
 - it only works if the extension has been enabled at one point during the session; otherwise the extension code hasn't been loaded yet and `stateObj` is undefined
 - if an extension only targets "special" modes, then it may not be prepared to be loaded in the regular user session (which would be necessary to check for and maybe run the `uninstall()` hook)

It also doesn't help that the hook only works if the extension is installed in HOME (as recommended), but not when using system packages.

target_title: Add uninstall hook for extensions

note.body:
Yes, I noticed the UNINSTALLED state, but the problem is that it's set after the extension has been disabled, so, if I get it right, it couldn't do anything. I mean: for an extension to know that the state has changed to UNINSTALLED, it would need to connect a signal to receive changes in the state, but when an extension is disabled, it must disconnect any signal, so...

About the "cleanup"... it would require to be able to specify paths relative to $HOME, at least... Not sure...

target_title: Flood of `g_object_get_qdata: assertion 'G_IS_OBJECT (object)` messages
Add uninstall hook for extensions

note.body:
It's worth pointing out there is a `UNINSTALLED` state for extensions, but there's a comment noting that it is only used in case of an unexpected error.

See:
 - https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/-/blob/main/js/misc/extensionUtils.js#L25-27
 - https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/blob/main/js/ui/extensionSystem.js#L454

Another option may be a `cleanup` variable in `metadata.json` holding an array of path globs, somewhat like Flatpak manifests. This would be less flexible than an `uninstall()` hook, but maybe easier to prevent accidental data loss if an extension author makes a mistake? Maybe the user could be prompted as well, if the UX for that was thought out a bit.

Just my two-cents :)

target_title: loginDialog: Support loading banner message from file
Power Off + Restart from Lock screen When Physical Access

note.body:
For what I see, I believe a _simpler_ implementation would be to add the Restart and Power-Off options, and Power-Off button modifiers if approved, available at the lock screen and greeter. When the user clicks on them, it would ask for credentials to check if the user is super-administrator.

Otherwise, a more fine-grained implementation would be a 2/3-part:

## 1 - Add Setting

    Privacy & Security → Lock Screen
    Bool: Allow to restart or shutdown from the lock screen or greet screen
    Description: Anyone will be able restart or shutdown the device.

## 2 - Add modifiers to use with the Power Button

Anywhere, using the Power Button with a keyboard modifier should restart or power-off the device. These modifiers are up to debate.

- `[CTRL + Power]`: Restart
- `[ALT + CTRL + Power]`: Shutdown

> I think these modifiers should avoid accidental pressing.

These _should_ work regardless of the prior setting, since hardware access is considered holy.

## 3. Prompt the user for restart/power-off

If GNOME can detect an application preventing shutdown, otherwise only detecting if at least one user session is open, should warn the user _before_ proceeding with the restart/power-off with the following prompt:

    Users using this device may lose unsaved work. Proceed with the restart/power-off?
    
    Cancel | Restart/Power-off anyway

@DartDeaDia :

> The example with **"CorporateSecretEditor is preventing shutdown due to: Unsaved secret_corporate_plan.doc. Shut down anyway?"** doesn't make sense in the context of the lock screen. As far as I remember, if you try to Shutdown or Restart your computer from the lock screen in Windows, it displays a message something like **"This device could loose unsaved work"** with a button next to it that says **"Shut down anyway"**. So, of course, nothing sensitive will be displayed in this case.

Consider reading https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/-/issues/8047#note_2270733 which already addressed this concern

_Note that "unsaved work" is not the only concern written in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/-/issues/8047#summary (summary) though_

target_title: Power mode affects Multiple Displays

note.body:
> Like adding some:
>
> ```
> WMClassByWindowName=Repetier-Host V2.3.2
> WMClassByWindowNameTimeout=3s
> WMClassByWindowNameValue=Repetier-Host
> ```

Sorry, but absolutely not. Not setting any WM_CLASS at all is extremely fringe, and I wouldn't be surprised if the proposed workaround of using a (temporarily) predictable window title instead would be limited to exactly that one app.

It looks like the app is using the mono framework, which could take care of setting a default WM_CLASS (using the name of the executed binary without the .exe suffix).

If that's not possible, then Sebastian's suggestion of packaging the app as flatpak is a good option.

I'm open to suggestions for generally improving app matching (like matching by systemd slice), but adding hackish workarounds with very limited applicability is a no-go.

target_title: Application not following icon set on desktop entry

note.body:
The suggested workaround does not seem very user friendly nor particularly robust. Requiring every user to modify their .desktop files manually would be bad and if this was applied upstream that raises the question why not to fix it properly by setting the correct `WM_CLASS`, which would be less lines of codes and not require constant updates depending on what the window title is going to be in the next release. Also it would break if the application opens windows with different titles (such as "Settings") or starts including the opened file name in the window title.

A better workaround without having to touch the code or somehow change the WM_CLASS would be to package the app as flatpak (or snap), which should result in all windows created by that app automatically being associated with it.

target_title: appDisplay: Add back X-GNOME-Utilities category in default Utilities folder?

note.body:
I think we need GNOME Design Team help.

I believe that the current app grid does not have a very logical layout and I was intending to try to draw attention to this during this development cycle.

In 2021, the GNOME Design Team intentionally moved apps out of the Utilities app folder apparently only because they wanted to demonstrate that the app grid supports multiple pages. See #3122 and https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/-/commit/1a2c9328

My opinion is that should not be a goal. That goal doesn't make as much sense as it did then because the app grid dimensions now differ based on screen size. It caused an arbitrary split of which apps were in the folder and which weren't. And there has been drift over time as what is in core GNOME has changed.

Having too many apps in the default app grid contributes to GNOME feeling cluttered and leaves less room for the apps that users intentionally install.

note.body:
Sorry for late replay, was out for weekend and than had no time to come and check the issue, BUT!! when I did, I stumbled upon something that changes everything I wrote above previously.

I was playing with this "click outside the window" thing and by pure luck found out that I was completely wrong - I indeed CAN resize the windows! - although I don’t know if it was always like this or I changed something that affected the behaviour, but in any case I did not experienced this before.

So, long story short, I found out that there is a “sweet spot” to position the cursor, which is  some ~2mm outside the border (same 12 px? I don't know). I mean, if I just put the cursor there or move around, nothing happens, BUT,however if I press mouse button while the arrow is in the correct (i.e. ~2mm/12px? out) position and do NOT release it, the cursor changes to correct resizing shape and I can resize the window as it should be! However it is impossible to say whether or not the cursor is in the correct position before pressing the mouse button. And if the mouse button was pressed in the wrong place, moving the mouse around does not help, I have to release the button and try again in another place.

This is awfully inconvenient on the one hand and 10 billion times better than it was before on the other hand.

Power Off + Restart from Lock screen When Physical Access

note.body:
Okay. The Power button doesn't work to shutdown the system when the shell is on lockdown. It only works for sleep.

I believe this should be on System Settings, on the General section, with a simple toggle:

    Title: **Allow power button to work on lockscreen **
    Options: [Boolean]
    Description: Any user with hardware access may be able to shutdown or restart the system.

If possible, an additional option to allow pressing the button with keyboard modifiers to enable restart or shutdown by hardware, if the above **is true**.


    Title: **Power button + CTRL restarts the system**
    Options: [Boolean]
    Description: Using SHIFT will forcefully restart the system.
    
    Title: **Power button + ALT powers off the system**
    Options: [Boolean]
    Description: Using SHIFT will forcefully shut down the system.

> The idea of using `SHIFT` its becase, when not done, the shell should tell the user there are apps preventing the power cycle, like unsaved documents. By doing SHIFT, you agree to bypass that and kill all processes. If it cannot be implemented,  it may be safely disregarded.

This enables using only the power button to sleep, without having to sacrifice power off and restart functionality on the lock screen.

target_title: Power Off + Restart from Lock screen When Physical Access

note.body:
God I have a lot of typos. Put this instead:

> The Power Button should be more _practical_. Its preference _could_ be overridden when using modifier keys along the Power Button, even when locked down, as opt-in:
>
> * `[ALT] + [Power]` to shut down.
> * `[ALT] + [SHIFT] + [Power]` to shut down immediately.
> * `[CTRL] + [Power]` to restart.

note.body:
I don't know if anyone said it, but the shut down button behavior _should_ override any lockscreen and give the system 60 seconds to shut down like normal.

The Power Button should be more _practical_ if you have access to it, using modifier to override the system preferences:

- `[ALT] + [Power]` to shut down.
- `[ALT] + [SHIFT] + [Power]` to shut down immediately.
- `[CTRL] + [Power]` to restart.
- `[CTRL] + [SHIFT] + [Power]` to restart immediately.

(Powering off should be less accidental than to restart, that's why `ALT`).

If there are apps asking for user intervention, you could tell the user the number of apps instead of anything else. Like _"One application is preventing shutdown. Proceed anyway?".

Since I have physical access to the device, not being able to shut it down resorts to pulling the plug or keep the power button for some seconds.

On the GNOME Settings side of things, there should be an option to tell the user if he wants to be able to shut down the computer in the UI while locked and confirm by admin password.

note.body:
> I also find this argument incoherent with one of your previous argument :

How so? 

> The vast majority of non tech savvy users who want to shutdown their locked PC would prefer to turn it off by hardware (usually less than 3 seconds) instead of typing the password and turning it off by software (at least 3x the time and efforts)

You could argue the same against use of polkit. There are lots of people who hate typing in their password whenever they need to do some more important change on the computer. Yes, the user would save several seconds, but from security standpoint it's just dumb. 

Why spent time and effort on something that doesn't really fix the problem (see my replies above)?

> 6 of them already shutdown by hardware

They are lazy. I cannot say anything else, they are just lazy. And you basically said that _even_ if someone did implement what you want it wouldn't do much, coz people would still do power shutdown. So not only this change wouldn't eliminate this problem, it would also introduce another one (again, see my replies above). 

> I do not have the pretention to make people change how they behave when it comes with some added slight frustration

Okay, but what's the alternative here? What you're arguing here is arguably worse than status quo. 

I think I said everything that I can say here, anything more and I would be just repeating myself. 

And about the poll: Right now just 120 people voted, i would wait with verdict until more people voted.

note.body:
> Unless said user is in extreme edge case, i don't think it's much of a problem

I think you widely underestimate how even slightly frustrating flow are avoided with easier and faster workarounds such as power shutdown

Those are common occurrences that UX/UI devs and designers face on a daily basis

The vast majority of non tech savvy users who want to shutdown their locked PC would prefer to turn it off by hardware (usually less than 3 seconds) instead of typing the password and turning it off by software (at least 3x the time and efforts)

See [the poll on r/GNOME about it](https://www.reddit.com/r/gnome/s/IlbIzrm5r7)

As of 2024-11-10T13:19:12+00:00, ≈ 1/3 (31/100) of r/GNOME members (overwhelmingly way more tech savvy than the average computer user) are using partially or exclusively hardware turn off (as of now, drawing any concluding from this poll would be premature)

Before posting, I observed 12 of my "Average user working using Windows computers" colleagues shut down their computers : 6 of them already shutdown by hardware (even when there is an option to turn it off by software when locked on Windows), and I'm quite positive it would go up to at least 10 if there were no software option to turn it off by software, like current GNOME

I know it can be difficult to fathom for tech savvy people (which I also am) because, if you are reading this message, you also are at the very least in the top 3 percentile of the most tech savvy people in the world

> Or just spending those several seconds to type in a password. It's a nonissue

Having worked in UX/UI design and development, I do not have the pretention to make people change how they behave when it comes with some added slight frustration (even if it has advantages I also acknowledge) anymore

This argument seemingly also goes in direct contradiction with your previous argument :

> majority of the users just straight up ignore the warning thinking "it's probably nothing serious", and click "yes", even if they did have some important unfinished work

note.body:
> However, someone that wants to turn off their computer will quickly find a way to turn it off, up to power shutdown if no alternative is found in a few seconds

That's 100% user issue. Waiting a few seconds to type in a password, saving unsaved stuff and turning off the computer will take maximally half a minute (of course please take it with a grain of salt, every user have their own pace and it's not something I'm trying to shame here). Unless said user is in extreme edge case, i don't think it's much of a problem.

> Even if it was just for that, it is still better

Is it? It's literally almost exact same problem, but with new dialog option and settings for customizing it. I would even argue that it's worse, coz it's not solving much, instead it's adding more confusion due to adding new option to change. There's a reason why GNOME doesn't expose much customization in the settings/tweaks and part of it is because it's always/mostly at the expense of forcing user to spend extra time to think whether they want this or not. GNOME is about sensible defaults after all. 

> With any other security prompt normal flow, there is no alternative but to pass the security check (in that case, authentication)

Or just spending those several seconds to type in a password. It's a nonissue.

target_title: Power Off + Restart from Lock screen When Physical Access

note.body:
> The only difference here from power shutdown is that it's not really possible to damage your hardware this way.

Even if it was just for that, it is still better

> majority of the users just straight up ignore the warning thinking "it's probably nothing serious", and click "yes", even if they did have some important unfinished work

Possible indeed

However, someone that wants to turn off their computer will quickly find a way to turn it off, up to power shutdown if no alternative is found in a few seconds

> It's similar thing with polkit asking user for password

The difference is specifically the reason why I created this issue in the first place : 

Someone that wants to turn off their computer will quickly find a way to turn it off, up to power shutdown if no alternative is found in a few seconds

With any other security prompt normal flow, there is no alternative but to pass the security check (in that case, authentication)

target_title: Power Off + Restart from Lock screen When Physical Access

note.body:
> You could show the "These sessions have unfinished work" dialog instead, avoiding leaks of private information and stating that shutting down the PC right now could cause data loss for someone else who has been using the PC.

I'm sorry, but this reminds me of "Yes, do as I say" from Linus' video from several years ago. Yes, it _is_ something, but majority of the users just straight up ignore the warning thinking "it's probably nothing serious", and click "yes", even if they did have some important unfinished work. The only difference here from power shutdown is that it's not really possible to damage your hardware this way. 

> This behavior is an intentional trade-off (+ security ; - practicality)

It's similar thing with polkit asking user for password. There are definitely people (and I don't think that group is small) who think that it's annoying, but, at the end of the day, it's just several seconds of typing in a password, it's not really difficult nor time-consuming. I think changing current behavior wouldn't really help eliminate the problem, it would just create another, very similar one (see above).

note.body: I have the exact opposite experience with Ubuntu where most configuration apps and utilities are in the main grid and it looks awful. Of course, it is debatable whether user apps like Loupe should be hidden inside this directory, but the directory itself is **very important** for its purpose, at least in my opinion.

target_title: appDisplay: Add back X-GNOME-Utilities category in default Utilities folder?

note.body:
> it's surprising if a newly installed app is hidden away in a folder

I've had this experience regularly, and always found it a bit surprising

target_title: System menu: No icons and text shown on buttons

note.body: This comment from what `nmcli c` uses to display the connection name might be relevant here: https://github.com/NetworkManager/NetworkManager/blob/0bac01b13373ef36a0b171ea2462885139cf5796/src/nmcli/connections.c#L638

target_title: GNOME-Shell often crashes when fullscreen application happens (Firefox video or screen lock even)

note.body:
The backtrace is probably due to https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/-/issues/7339. Does this still happen when all extensions are disabled?

That's probably different from the fullscreen video case. For the fullscreen case, are you using an AMD GPU and does gnome-shell get killed rather than crashes? In that case there would be no core dump, but just a `org.gnome.Shell@wayland.service: Main process exited, code=killed, status=9/KILL` in the logs.

target_title: GNOME-Shell often crashes when fullscreen application happens (Firefox video or screen lock even)

note.body: the last error line does not look promising though…

target_title: GNOME-Shell often crashes when fullscreen application happens (Firefox video or screen lock even)
appDisplay: Add org.gnome.Console to X-GNOME-Shell-Utilities
Draft: screencastService: Add AV1 and VP8 VA-API pipelines

note.body: Looks like `libva-intel-media-driver` Fedora 41 doesn't come with encoders (apart from jpeg). Would be nice to at least have the VP8 encoder in to have hw-encoding OOTB.

target_title: Draft: screencastService: Add AV1 and VP8 VA-API pipelines

push_data.commit_title: appDisplay: Fix Fonts desktop file name

target_title: appDisplay: Fix Fonts desktop file name
appDisplay: Fix Fonts desktop file name

note.body:
Whoops.

Apparently https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-font-viewer/-/commit/2a7a60e99997a01271dbd51896bf97f3fc0d2d0e covered up that error, which won't work anymore now that the folder no longer has a corresponding category.

target_title: appDisplay: Fix Fonts desktop file name
appDisplay: Add back X-GNOME-Utilities category in default Utilities folder?
data: Add X-GNOME-Utilities.directory file from gnome-menus

note.body:
> Maybe we should add back the `category: 'X-GNOME-Utilities'` field after all.

Now I'm having second thoughts about that.

On the one hand, the category keeps apps in the folder even when the app is renamed.

On the other hand, it's surprising if a newly installed app is hidden away in a folder.

Right now I tend towards prioritizing the latter, but mostly adding a comment so the thread can be moved to a new issue.

target_title: Allow to screencast without sound and without pipewire

note.body: I suggest asking the PipeWire project how to configure it to work like that. FWIW, we used it for screen recording before it was used as the default audio server in the past, so at least it *was* possible before.

target_title: Allow to screencast without sound and without pipewire

note.body: Thanks for the quick response! So should it be possible to use pipewire for the compositor, and pulseaudio for the sound?

target_title: Allow to screencast without sound and without pipewire

note.body: Pipewire is not used for sound recording. In fact the screen recorder does not even support audio capture. Pipewire is used to send buffers containing the video frames from the compositor to the recording process, in this case the gnome-shell screencast service. You don't even need to use pipewire as sound server for that. There are no plans to support video recording without pipewire.

Sorry, I meant replacing the name in places like [this one](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-menus/-/blob/master/layout/gnome-applications.menu?ref_type=heads#L29) (although I am not sure whether this list is used anymore).

target_title: data: Add X-GNOME-Utilities.directory file from gnome-menus

note.body:
Not sure about dropping the `X-` prefix. The [menu spec](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/menu-spec/latest/) apparently only mandates to "namespace" custom directories, but the prefix is quite well established.

Maybe `X-GNOME-Shell-Utilities`? It's ambiguous ("utilities with GNOME-Shell prefix" vs. "Shell-Utilities with GNOME prefix"), but that shouldn't be too much of a deal given the filename isn't user-visible.

target_title: data: Add X-GNOME-Utilities.directory file from gnome-menus

note.body:
Removing the old file from gnome-menus is fine, although the component is pretty much unmaintained and I therefore wouldn't count on distros updating it, even with a new upstream release.

> or replace them with the new `GNOME-Utilities.directory` name

Definitely not, the whole point of using a different name is to avoid a file conflict with gnome-menus.

I don't expect things like Flashback or GNOME Classic to display the directory, because it's always empty. Menu editors like alacarte probably show it, but they should simply use a default icon instead of getting messed up.

3. use new clutter-backend property

In any case LGTM

note.body:
> This has been merged into main, but not into gnome-46 where the bug occurs.

That suggests that the issue was not present on main ("the bug occurs on gnome-46"), which is bogus. The bug was introduced by commit dde13b30c, so all branches that carry the commit are affected (main, gnome-46 and gnome-47).

I generally prefer to do bulk-backports in the run-up to a release, which is why the commit hasn't been backported yet. I don't mind cherry-pick this out-of-order if you prefer, but then please open another MR for gnome-47. *Either* cherry-picking the commit before the release *or* skipping it because it was already applied work for me, but I don't want a mix of both.

target_title: screenshot is not actually copied

note.body:
> i can paste them after copying the saved image from Image Viewer (loupe), so it's a problem in shell

Not necessarily. The shell copies the screenshot as image data, loupe copies the file path. Not all drop targets accept all types, for example nautilus doesn't support image data.

Polari, Fractal and gtk4-demo's "clipboard" are examples for targets that accept image data, and I cannot reproduce the issue with those.

the power button would have send the entire device into suspend. Doing this while upgrading a package or the entire system ( like in this case ), would certainly break something in the process.

As it's a mouse less device, you can't push a mouse to unblank the screen, nor press a key on a phy. keyboard. 

DNF sets an inhibitor, so it does not get disturbed by a poweroff/reboot, but I'm not sure, if that stops suspend from happening and i was not eager to find it out in mid fedora 41 upgrade ;) 

I would suggest to check for that inhibitor, before auto blanking the screen. If the user decides to blank the screen with a click, fine, his problem.

note.body:
> Wouldn't the work area also change arbitrarily depending on size or settings of a dock or dimensions of the display? For instance a side dock on a wider aspect ratio display would only offset it a smaller amount compared to a narrower one, so it would be in arbitrary positions based on user's setup. And would autohiding the dock while an OSD is on screen shift the position of it since the workarea is dynamic?

Nope, when a dock/panel is in auto-hide mode, the workarea is by default the whole available screen, since the dock/panel doesn't really confine the workarea in such case, but it's more likely a gadget.

note.body:
I would have to agree with Florian. Tweaking the colour temperature of the Night Light setting is not something that is as frequently tweaked as brightness or volume to require a top-level slider.

I could see a case being made that a submenu of the Night Light toggle itself could exist where a slider like this could go plus a shortcut to Night Light settings panel, but I am still not convinced there's being a big enough use case to cater to that.

target_title: Keep grabbed window stuck to cursor through workspace transisitions
osdWindow: Use work area aware monitor constraint

note.body:
The bounds of what is considered a workarea seems a bit fuzzy and open to interpretation. 
Semantically, they are system/device feedback not workspace ones so their framing with respect to the whole display makes more sense.

Wouldn't the work area also change arbitrarily depending on size or settings of a dock or dimensions of the display? For instance a side dock on a wider aspect ratio display would only offset it a smaller amount compared to a narrower one, so it would be in arbitrary positions based on user's setup. And would autohiding the dock while an OSD is on screen shift the position of it since the workarea is dynamic?

In any case, keeping them centered to the display is more desirable from the design POV as they will always be in a consistent position for all GNOME users. (Were this to be a change, I can also forsee people complaining about "my OSD are off-center!" who have the contrary view about workarea-positioning.)

target_title: screenshot is not actually copied

Group/bundle/reuse previously missed transient screenshot notifications

note.body:
My mother is 68 and uses GNOME 47, and just mentioned again to me today how annoyed she is with GNOME's screenshot notifications.

She takes a lot of screenshots, sometimes 40 screenshots per gaming session, and as soon as she closes the game, the desktop begins spamming her with piled-up Screenshot notifications, and as soon as she closes one, another pops up. They obscure her desktop work and she just has to sit there and wait.

Then when she looks in the Notification drawer (top center of screen) the Screenshots completely dominate the list, drowning out all other app notifications. Same thing on the lock screen. It is so messy that our only resort is "Clear All" to start over.

It also causes lots of lag when opening the Notification drawer. Can take many, many seconds to show the list when a lot of them have piled up.

She has resorted to permanently using GNOME in "Do not disturb" mode which means she does not get information about new emails etc. All because the Screenshot tool in GNOME frustrates her so much.

The Screenshot tool singlehandedly makes GNOME Notifications panel awful to use.

I would propose a few things that would really help my dear old mother:

- A GSettings value to silence all screenshot notifications. She hates them and does not need them. This could be a good, fast stopgap solution while designing better solutions.
- Grouping notifications and making it easy to clear/dismiss just that group.
- Setting a limit to GNOME Screenshot notifications so if it hits 10 or so, it automatically dismisses the oldest one. So it cannot pile up and lag the entire notification panel. Can be implemented by letting apps query and dismiss their own notifications. Or by having an API for apps to "prune my own notifications: keep 10 notifications".

        save_stage = 1
        act = {__sigaction_handler = {sa_handler = 0x20, sa_sigaction = 0x20}, sa_mask = {__val =
{7162238673665485932, 7307218077898470753, 8392569456348324640, 8391173040912951584,

#9  0x00007f37c2146240 in amdgpu_ctx_set_sw_reset_status (rwctx=<optimized out>,
status=status@entry=PIPE_INNOCENT_CONTEXT_RESET, format=format@entry=0x7f37c3115088 "amdgpu: The CS has
cancelled because the context is lost. This context is innocent.\n") at
../src/gallium/winsys/amdgpu/drm/amdgpu_cs.cpp:459
        args = {{gp_offset = 24, fp_offset = 48, overflow_arg_area = 0x7f37c97feca0, reg_save_area =
0x7f37c97febe0}}
        ctx = <optimized out>
#10 0x00007f37c21496b0 in amdgpu_cs_submit_ib<false> (job=job@entry=0x55e3482b8070,
gdata=gdata@entry=0x0, thread_index=thread_index@entry=0) at

```
[connectivity]
enabled=false
```

Refer https://gitlab.gnome.org/Teams/Design/os-mockups/-/tree/master/lock-login for recent mock-ups by Allan.

As for the per-user login screen background, I think we should go with a single system level (but configurable) styling and not per-user styling. Main reason is displaying other user's background (even if blurred) might raise privacy concerns. My blind guess is almost 80% (including corporates preferring their logo etc and individual users) should be fine with this. Even if there is some reasoning to support per-user login screen background, it can be revisited after a few releases (when we have enough feedback from the community).

Yeah, my bad, I completely forgot about XWayland. It all makes sense now. Thanks for the clarification.

target_title: Tray icon X11 window size does not follow tray icon actor size

note.body:
> This is not quite true.

It is true: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/-/blob/c3cd21cc166989b3cf20b204e93f7a255b9af58c/src/shell-tray-icon.c#L97-99

What you are probably seeing is that if there is another unrelated X11 window in that area, mutter would still send the click event to XWayland and XWayland then determines that the click must have been on the tray plug window (not socket, the socket window does nothing when clicked on), but from the Wayland compositor perspective the click was on the unrelated x11 window. This does not happen if there is for example a native Wayland window or no other window at all, so you can right click on the desktop for example.

> Also, it seems to be fixed in the Ubuntu branch, exactly in this version: 46.0-0ubuntu6\~24.04.1

Those are the same patches from https://gitlab.gnome.org/3v1n0/gnome-shell/-/commits/tray-offscreen-xwindows that were discussed here before. There is no upstream MR for those yet though.

target_title: Tray icon X11 window size does not follow tray icon actor size

note.body:
> but is made invisible in `shell_tray_icon_window_created_cb()` and is set to ignore clicks on Wayland

This is not quite true. It is invisible in Wayland but still registers every click and opens a new instance of AnyDesk. It also stays on top of every application you launch, using 200x200px of your screen as a giant big button to launch itself.

Also, it seems to be fixed in the Ubuntu branch, exactly in this version: 46.0-0ubuntu6~24.04.1

Worth a look and adding this fix here, I guess.

target_title: data: Add X-GNOME-Utilities.directory file from gnome-menus

note.body: Interesting. So there's no way to change it just from a static translation? I think doing `_('Utilities')` and marking it untranslatable is a clear improvement over the status qou. You tell me as maintainer what do you prefer, not sure how often do people change the language of their systems.

target_title: data: Add X-GNOME-Utilities.directory file from gnome-menus

note.body:
> Why not directly give the folder a real name `Utilities`, and make it translatable?

You mean marking the folder as untranslated, but use `_('Utilities')` as its name? That's possible, but means the folder name is determined at creation time, i.e. the name isn't updated when the user changes the display language.

target_title: cleanup: Don't use private struct for final types

note.body:
> So I suppose they have to be fixed and make them use the `G_DECLARE_DERIVABLE_TYPE` instead

At least for BoxLayout that seems the best option. It's subclassed quite a bit, and expecting every list-like actor to either use an internal `this._box` or hook up a `Clutter.LayoutManager` layout with CSS styling is a bit much.

`Label` and `Icon` on the other hand feel much more "final", so it may be better to change those subclasses to a bin+label/bin+icon pattern.

target_title: data: Add X-GNOME-Utilities.directory file from gnome-menus

note.body: If we are going to do that... Why not directly give the folder a real name `Utilities`, and make it translatable? Then we can get rid of the whole process of having to read a desktop file just to pick a translation?

target_title: data: Add X-GNOME-Utilities.directory file from gnome-menus

note.body:
That is, I'd simply use
```suggestion:-1+0
    input: 'X-GNOME-Utilities.directory.desktop.in',
    output: '@BASENAME@',
```
here, without the loop

target_title: data: Add X-GNOME-Utilities.directory file from gnome-menus

note.body:
That seems a bit overkill?

At this point it seems much more likely that we ditch the existing default folder, than add additional ones.

target_title: data: Add X-GNOME-Utilities.directory file from gnome-menus

note.body: Drop both `Comment` and `Icon`. They aren't required according to [the spec](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/1.1/recognized-keys.html#id-1.6.6), we don't use those fields for the folder, and nothing else should display the directory (it's empty as far as the menu entry spec is concerned).

target_title: data: Add X-GNOME-Utilities.directory file from gnome-menus

note.body:
I think it is a good call to not depend on gnome-menus for translating the default folder.

*But*: Having both gnome-shell and gnome-menus provide the same file is highly problematic, not only for package managers.

If gnome-menus was an active component with regular releases according to the gnome schedule, we could remove the .directory from there, but that's very clearly not the case (it's still at 3.36.0!).

That is, use a different filename for the .directory file, and adjust the corresponding [folder code](js/ui/appDisplay.js#L61). While at it, I'd also drop the `X-GNOME-Utilities` from the categories - we don't actually use the menu definition from gnome-menus, and it's not a category that apps list themselves, so it's completely unused anyway.

target_title: data: Add X-GNOME-Utilities.directory file from gnome-menus

note.body:
> I wonder if it'd make more sense to drop gnome-menus by now and stop creating this weird default folder?

I'd be all in for that... But, if it needs quite a sizable amount of discussions, then I'd really appreciate if we could merge this, and open an issue to discuss with the relevant people, to see how to do that. I'm very happy to be the one doing those code changes. I just don't want to block this on that (possibly long) discussion taking place.

target_title: toolbox: Add tooling for exporting system extension from container

note.body:
> [sysext-utils](https://gitlab.gnome.org/tchx84/sysext-utils) addresses that by building a per-project sysext, but that makes it harder to work on both mutter and the shell in parallel. Manually composing which projects go in the sysext makes that easy, but it has the obvious downside that you can miss a hard dependency.

sysext-utils also allows building a sysext from an arbitrary tree directory, which is what we use for mutter and gnome-shell CI.

We basically keep adding stuff to the extension/ directory (dependencies, mutter, gnome-shell) and only then build one sysext out of that extension/ directory.

Isn't that what's being done here?

target_title: restarting gnome-shell breaks current session and user is logged out
toolbox: Add tooling for exporting system extension from container

note.body:
Yes, SELinux has to be turned off for now. I'll see if I can get that fixed, although I'm very much not an SELinux expert.

But this reminds me that I'll have to write up some documentation before this is merged :-)

Some other open questions that would be good to address before:
 - would sudo be better than pkgexec? I find that I mostly call the script from a terminal, so having a system prompt pop up is a bit distracting (also sudo caches the credentials, so can be more convenient when updating frequently)
 - in hindsight, "sysext-update" isn't the most accurate name, but not sure what really describes "copy sysext dir from toolbox to host, set it up sysext and merge". "sysext-install" is slightly better, but it conflicts with the same command from sysext-utils. Any suggestions?

> Forgot to `meson-build.sh --sysext` for mutter which obviously blew up. Not sure if we can do anything about this.

Not sure either. [sysext-utils](https://gitlab.gnome.org/tchx84/sysext-utils) addresses that by building a per-project sysext, but that makes it harder to work on both mutter and the shell in parallel. Manually composing which projects go in the sysext makes that easy, but it has the obvious downside that you can miss a hard dependency.

Maybe we should modify the `update-mutter` command we install inside the toolbox to also install to the sysext extension? That would at least fix it for people who don't pass `--skip-mutter` when creating the toolbox ...
