target_title: [46.6] Graphical artifacts in the power off / restart / log out dialog box buttons.

note.body:
I can reproduce as well. Fedora 40, GNOME 46.6, Framework Laptop 16, with the Ryzen 7 7840HS APU and with Radeon 780M graphics. Running Linux kernel 6.11.3 and `amd-gpu-firmware` version 20241017-1.fc40. I tried downgrading to `amd-gpu-firmware-20240312-1.fc40.noarch`, but that didn't help.

![Screenshot_from_2024-10-21_18-20-07](/uploads/49eac67528daa5775bb92264524f7401/Screenshot_from_2024-10-21_18-20-07.png)

Might or might not be related - I have also gotten other graphical artifacts after installing this update. For example, closing the "power off" dialog occasionally causes a portion of the screen to artifact and briefly show a grid of squares. On top of this, a white line has been spotted occasionally towards the middle of the screen, and I have had a couple black screens.

Right when I was making this comment, for example, the entire screen went black (backlight was still on) for a split second and then it recovered. Unfortunately, this left no longs in either `dmesg` or `journalctl -xe`.

Happy to follow up is further testing or logs are needed.

note.body:
The lack of space seems on purpose, though? The modal dialog in my screenshot has about the same amount of width used, and the windows screenshot doesn't really seem wider as well.

From an accessibility standpoint I think it would be more useful if it just opened the same dialog as the settings app (bonus points for me since there is a bug where my headset cannot be connected from the quick settings toggle, and only from that dialog for some reason).

Or, if that is not possible, then using the same semantic scheme as the pills (accent color for activated, backgorund color for deactivated), and using a UI like the one in MacOS would make it more consistent at least:

![image](/uploads/0729c581090920823e5419efcb2d4225/image.png)

Another possibility is something like the [Bluetooth Battery Meter](https://extensions.gnome.org/extension/6670/bluetooth-battery-meter/) extension, which uses a tri-state icon next to the device name to display the connection status and looks a lot more actionable than the faded label:

![image](/uploads/6a225a70c32452fcd997e5cb1cd7d5f5/image.png)

gnome-shell gets killed after connecting usb c cable on AMD GPU when run without MUTTER_DEBUG_KMS_THREAD_TYPE=user
gnome-shell gets killed after connecting usb c cable on AMD GPU when run without MUTTER_DEBUG_KMS_THREAD_TYPE=user

note.body: It prevents the KMS thread from becoming a realtime thread. If a realtime thread becomes stalled for too long, it gets killed by the kernel. The KMS thread is primarily interacting with the graphics driver and some drivers (most frequently AMD) can stall for long enough in some situations and trigger this. For some situations there are workarounds in the form of temporarily disabling realtime for that thread.

note.body:
With KeePassXC, the problem rather seems to be that it uses Qt5 and Qt5 does not properly support xdg-activation for startup notification. The `StartupWMClass` should not interfere with the match for the file name, which matches `org.keepassxc.KeePassXC` and seems to be needed for X11 where the `WM_CLASS` is indeed `KeePassXC`.

> But running keepassxc directly from command line makes it appear in alt tab menu immediately.

That's because startup notification is not used then. It is only used when gnome-shell starts an application and the application indicates that it supports startup notification.

target_title: Some apps take a long time to appear in Alt + Tab menu in GNOME

note.body:
In the case of KeePassXC, the issue seems to be that it has the following in its .desktop file:
```
StartupWMClass=keepassxc
StartupNotify=true
```

That means that gnome-shell considers the app in "starting" state until a window identified by "keepassxc" appears and notifies that it started successfully.

But then the actual wm class / app-id of its window is `org.keepassxc.KeePassXC`, so the app stays stucked in "starting" state until gnome-shell considers it failed after a timeout.

I don't know about cosmic term. They don't appear to set a WMClass in [the .desktop file](https://github.com/pop-os/cosmic-term/blob/master/res/com.system76.CosmicTerm.desktop), so it will be something else.

But given that their immediate response was "report to GNOME, it's their issue" without any apparent investigation, I don't feel motivated installing the app and running it with `WAYLAND_DEBUG=1` to see if they do implement xdg-activation as claimed, and if yes, whether there's an incompatibility between their implementation and mutter (and who's more likely in the wrong) ...

note.body:
More observations:
1. In ~50% cases, when re-opening the app folder after moving one of its apps back to the main grid, a first page of the app folder is displayed. Sometimes, it is glitched as on the previous picture, in other cases the app icons look normal, just the sliders on the sides of the app folder are broken.
2. In other cases, when re-opening the app folder after moving one of its apps back to the main grid, a second page (or the page the app was moved from) is displayed. And in many cases, it is not even possible to switch back to the first page - it always moves back to the second one. :smile: See [this screencast](/uploads/b02cdd90e998939ab052559f75d280ba/another_glitch.mp4).
3. When the app folder gets glitched, it is not possible to click to close it. Only clicking on the GNOME Shell top bar or pressing Esc closes it. Clicking anywhere else has no effect.

Also, the bug seems to only occur when moving an app from the app folder back into the main app grid, not the other way around.

I was able to find some errors in my system journal, but they appeared afterwards, when I was trying to move other apps in the main grid (outside of the app folder) and creating a new folder. They are probably unrelated.

note.body: If you want truly smooth scrolling then I think the input position has to be slightly decoupled from the scroll position. Instead the scroll velocity should just scale to match the input velocity. This way the scrolling frame rate should always be the native frame rate and you're immune to jitter from the input stream. AFAICT native touch platforms like iOS and Android seem to do this, but most desktop Linux toolkits don't.

target_title: gnome-shell crashes on login or when opening the notification panel when connected to a wifi with captive portal

note.body: Here's more background on the issue that future readers might find interesting. Use of global (or thread-local) variables has always been a major pain point in libxml2 and there are many similar issues in downstream code. We have [gradually introduced](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libxml2/-/issues/407) new API functions that avoid global state. Since version 2.13, you can use `xmlCtxtSetErrorHandler` to set a local error handler. Unfortunately, it will take some time until the new API is widely available.

target_title: gnome-shell crashes on login or when opening the notification panel when connected to a wifi with captive portal

note.body:
That crash is triggered by an error message when parsing malformed weather data, which is what happens when opening the date menu. The data is malformed because of the captive portal replacing the expected XML with its own content. libxml2 tries to log the error about the malformed input using the global libxml2 error handler that was registered by libxkbcommon in [`parse()`](https://github.com/xkbcommon/libxkbcommon/blob/b8888345fe3a86737836c3302121f8c9c3e19b6b/src/registry.c#L1249C5-L1249C27). This error handler requires a valid libxkbcommon `rxkb_context` context since it calls a function pointed to by the context. Judging by the backtrace the context seems to have already been destroyed and (partially) overwritten by the time libgweather tries to parse the weather data, but the error handler is still set to the one from libxkbcommon. This would explain why there is a call to an unknown function at the end of the backtrace. The context would have gotten created and destroyed [in gnome-desktop when parsing xkb rules](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-desktop/-/blob/3bd4bdde4c37490058626ecdc80c593b48f20235/libgnome-desktop/gnome-xkb-info.c#L288) and the call to the `parse()` function that sets the error handler happens via `rxkb_context_parse()`.

I think this is a bug in libxkbcommon and it should restore the default error handler at the end of its `parse()` function, but I'm not really familiar with libxml2. @nwellnhof do you think this could be the cause of this issue?

target_title: status/keyboard: Fix execution order when activating source

note.body:
> I prefer activateInputSource() to be considered "sync" (or with "fire and forget" internals, if you prefer)

Fire and forget internal could also be guaranteed for the async function by using await for the results for currentSource "ask, and forget, when you receive, proceed" by any following code.

What is the upside or downside to doing that?

That would also prevent any bottlenecks would it not?

And sorry to keep bothering you, could that be more efficient, init everything, and as things resolve, keep executing subsequent code?

target_title: status/keyboard: Fix execution order when activating source

note.body:
I appreciate the very clear explanation, thank you.

I just want to understand one other issue-

> I prefer activateInputSource() to be considered "sync" (or with "fire and forget" internals, if you prefer) so we avoid the only plausible situation where the source may be null during init

How does this fix, even with sync code, or prior code insure that activateInputSource() is always called before initiation and the call to setKeys() through the constructor in Keyboard.js, or constructors in other classes?  Or before the value for currentSource is set within the synchronous function? Would that not be another situation where the source could be null during init?

ie is it possible that the source could be still returned null to constructors in other classes during initiation with race conditions?

With !3496, I was getting the currentSource with just the signal emitted after the source was set, while F. Mullener got a blank keyboard, meaning Keyboard.js likely connected to the signal after it was fired, attesting to the fact that there are certainly some timing differences from one situation to another.

From my reading of the code, it seems activateInputSource() is called after initiation by another function that gets the default gsettings, that are likely being read from disc.

In which case, would it not also be better to deal with a possible null during initiation for the code assessing currentSource to prevent similar, even if unlikely, but not impossible crash in future.

It should be taken seriously since this issue may put off many people trying gnome for the first time.

target_title: status/keyboard: Fix execution order when activating source

note.body:
The only need for setEngine to have a callback in the past was that was so that we could call `KeyboardManager.releaseKeyboard()` at the end of the operation, this was necessary to send keyboard events in X11 to a sinkhole until the source was guaranteed to be changed, since otherwise the X11 keyboard events would reach the application, be handled by them, and fed to IBus independently. This was the X11 way of doing things, and it is inherently racy.

On pure Wayland, only Mutter/Shell interact with IBus directly, through their own IBus helper objects, I would rely that the IBus API would know to deal with its own possible race condition resulting from changing the engine while other events are queued up for processing, and if not it would probably deserve a bug in IBus.

I prefer activateInputSource() to be considered "sync" (or with "fire and forget" internals, if you prefer) so we avoid the only plausible situation where the source may be null during init, otherwise it will become a bottleneck for Shell initialization.

target_title: status/keyboard: Fix execution order when activating source

note.body: That makes sense, I pushed a commit that does this.

target_title: Sudden and frequent crashes after upgrade to GNOME 47 without MUTTER_DEBUG_KMS_THREAD_TYPE=user

note.body: So this is yet another case of gnome-shell getting killed due to the RT KMS thread being stalled for too long. There have been several reports about this for AMD GPUs. For example there is an issue where the amdgpu driver is taking really long to enable direct scanout, i.e. when opening a fullscreen window (https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/-/issues/3450) or when connecting/disconnecting monitors or on suspend/resume (https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/-/issues/3479). Are those maybe the situations in which you encountered the crash?

#!/bin/sh

target_title: status/keyboard: Fix execution order when activating source

note.body:
> I lean towards sync, since the only reason to make it otherwise is X11 legacy.

Could you explain that to me and the reasons behind it. That perhaps is the crux of the matter.

If we do keep it async-

The signal following async entrypoint is emitted at the correct time _after_ the engine is set.

The problem here is assessing the null value, which means that-
a. Never return a null value
b. Deal with a possible null value.

If we want to maintain a sync workflow following this call, we can _delay_ setup keys and initialization pending the signal. Please see !3496 

Or we want to be _absolutely_ correct every time, we could continue the async workflow, please see !3487. That is a much less invasive fix than my previous attempt that I closed. It maintains the sync getter API till it can be taken out later until the async API is used everywhere, which is also easy enough to do, please see the closed !3483, where I extended it to every call that used it.

What is the downside in continuing an async workflow? To me it sounds easy enough.

And please, I am not objecting to the fix, I am merely trying the understand and learn the reasoning, pro's and cons behind this approach and the others - so that I can code better next time.

target_title: status/keyboard: Fix execution order when activating source

note.body:
This strikes me as the simplest fix. And if we attain to keeping `activateInputSource` a synchronous API entrypoint (and declare making it async a blunder), the most correct.

I lean towards sync, since the only reason to make it otherwise is X11 legacy.

target_title: slider: Consider text direction when handling arrow keys

note.body:
> This is a boolean property, true/false returned, not the text-direction ENUM

You are missing the point.

You have to make a convincing argument that this one specific actor needs a special "is-rtl" boolean property, while the 4000+ *other* actors in gnome-shell don't.

target_title: slider: Consider text direction when handling arrow keys

note.body:
This is a boolean property, true/false returned, not the text-direction ENUM. The ENUM itself can be truthy or falsy but not true Javascript boolean.

Avoids having to get a boolean property by doing get_text_direction === Clutter.TextDirection.RTL every time you have to check for it and writing the same code again and again. And it is better to write it this way to make the meaning clear even though the underlying ENUM may be truthy or falsy.

Convenient shortcut added to the underlying widget on which the slider is based. Also replaces the same code in a vfunction in the underlying widget.

So why no?

But no big deal. If you want me to write 
````
const rtl = actor.get_text_direction() === Clutter.TextDirection.RTL
````
 everywhere, and then use that constant everywhere, then I can do that.

target_title: slider: Consider text direction when handling arrow keys

note.body: No. `get_text_direction()` is supported by every `Clutter.Actor`, and adding a special property to one particular actor doesn't make much sense.

ui/keyboard: updateKeys() via signal first in constructor, deal with potential null value.

note.body:
@fmuellner 

Sorry to waste your time again.

I can display the keyboard fine.

If you are not able to display the keyboard, then this is not a good fix.

The reason for that would be, that you are connecting to the signal _after_ it has fired. In which case pressing a key or changing the input method with the mouse, or any other method to trigger the signal to updateKeys() should display the keys.

Which means there is a race and we can never _guarantee_ the timing- either of the connecting to the signal on time, or with your approach, accessing the value before or after it is set.

The only __absolute__ way to do it would be to assess in asynchronously after it is set with an await/promise. That would _guarantee_ that code would execute only after the engine is set, and is not null. That way the code would always trigger correctly.

Any other way, including this one is actually a hack, and, in my opinion a poor design decision.

target_title: ui/keyboard: updateKeys() via signal first in constructor, deal with potential null value.

note.body:
I apologize for not checking in the running session, but I did check in the tools/toolbox and everything was running except the keyboard does not come up in toolbox check. Unfortunately, here the keyboard is empty,

How do you test in the running session? and I will do so next time as well.

I do not really hate the fix. However I do think it is the wrong approach. Just because I disagree does not mean that you cannot merge what you think is correct.

Your approach is to \_win\_ the race and set currentSource to a non null value before it is accessed. Nothing wrong with that. It is a very quick simple fix. Except the downside is that the signal is given at the wrong time, and there is, at least in my mind, no 100% assurance that it will still succeed every time.

My approach is entirely different.  I want to \_loose\_,  let the await async currentSource setting to win and succeed every time. I want to \_assure\_ and check that the currentSource is a non null valid value before proceeding with accessing the value, or alternatively \_delay\_ initializing the keyBoard \_updateKeys() that is accessing the null value,  till the value is non null.

There is only two ways of doing what I propose-

1\. Use signals - like I did in this version, however there still seems to be a race, and the signal is missed, and \_updateKeys() is not called.

2\. Use promises and or await to delay initialization of updateKeys() or assessing currentSource so that the error can never happen.

As this fix is not working and the signal is missed, means that, as everything is being initialized concurrently, there are too many unpredictable timing issues to predictably initialize using synchronous methods. It also reinforces my intuitive, though possibly naive idea, that initializing everything at the same time, even with your approach, does not assure things will always work correctly.

Therefore, I think, using promises and await is the correct solution - to either delay initialization or assess currentSource value. Even if this is not working as intended, using a await promise for \_updateKeys() here will definitely will, as the signal is not.

I am sorry that you feel that this is a massive waste of time. That is not my intention- to waste your time.

My intention is to have a meaningful, thoughtful discussion of the two approaches to fix the issue. And the pros and cons of each. And to figure out which one is better. And why?

Because this is hopefully an open source, healthy community. Which means that I, and others learn, contribute, and join the community, and hopefully write better code in future, and make Gnome better. And more people learn how you and other maintainers think the direction the code should go, and why.

And so, if and when you, or some other Gnome Maintainer has some time, please educate me, and hopefully others, and go over the pro's and cons of the two different approaches and which one is better long term and why, even if your solution is merged. I am not objecting to your merge. I am simply asking why that approach is better?

And please, you do not have to be sarcastic. That "someone" is just me currently, unless some other people have had the same idea and have not articulated it. My articulating alternative ideas does not make your fix less meaningful.

target_title: ui/keyboard: updateKeys() via signal first in constructor, deal with potential null value.

note.body:
This is what I get when I enable the OSK in the running session:

![Screenshot of on-screen keyboard without any keys](/uploads/7bded6a2ee59b527d976631ffe7df0b4/Screenshot_From_2024-10-08_15-06-20.png)

So no, I wouldn't call that "no need to call _updateKeys() in the constructor".

I get that for some reason, you really really *really* hate the existing fix, and therefore keep pumping out more and more alternatives. Fine, but if you feel the urge to keep doing that, please *please* genuinely test stuff before opening a merge request. In my head the issue is pretty much fixed(*) and checked off, so having to come back again and again for proposals that fall apart almost immediately in testing starts to feel like a massive waste of time.

(*) except that the fix hasn't been distributed to users yet, because "someone" insists that there must be an alternative

target_title: App grid icons look too big on 1600*900 on some displays

That was an [intentional change](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/-/merge_requests/3278). In general, staying closer to the (bigger) target icon size is considered good, because you get more details / less ellipsization.

Icons are clearly bigger on 1600x900 now, but why do you think they are too big?

note.body:
Hi @kr.woaini, that file contains no backtrace at all. 

Without a good stack trace from the crash it is very hard to find out why the crash happens. Can you please get us a stack trace which includes debug symbols? Please see https://handbook.gnome.org/issues/stack-traces.html for more information and also make sure it includes debug symbols.

**Only** if you do not have `systemd-coredump` installed on your system, instead follow https://wiki.gnome.org/GettingInTouch/Bugzilla/GettingTraces how to use `gdb` and also do make sure to install or compile debug symbols for the crashing application and the libraries used by it. In case you use Arch Linux, see https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Debug_-_Getting_Traces

target_title: Moving icons from the folder breaks the veiw of folder

note.body:
Fedora 40, gnome-shell-46.5-1.fc40.x86_64.

Dragging an app out of the app folder still causes the folder corners to glitch:

![app_folder_glitch](/uploads/a00f460824eef2a5c7ff87b484a07f9a/app_folder_glitch.mp4)

Closing and re-opening the Shell Overview does not fix the issue and user must log out in order to fix this.

Not sure if that matters, but I am using a laptop touchpad and running a Wayland session.

**edit:** Here are the complete steps to reproduce the bug:
1. Create a new application folder (or use an existing one) and make sure that it has at least two pages and at least two apps on the second page.
2. Close and re-open the Shell Overview mode after this (probably not necessary, but still a good idea to do that).
3. Click on the app folder and move one of the apps from this folder back to the main app grid.
4. Re-open the app folder and see how it looks like.

While I agree these "declare" macros are nice and fine and so on, they do not work well in this scenario, because their requirements cannot be satisfied without changes out of this project.

```
../src/calendar-server/reminder-watcher.h: In function ‘glib_autoptr_clear_ReminderWatcher’:
/usr/include/glib-2.0/glib/gmacros.h:1339:49: error: ‘glib_autoptr_clear_EReminderWatcher’ undeclared (first use in this function); did you mean ‘glib_autoptr_clear_ReminderWatcher’?
 1339 | #define _GLIB_AUTOPTR_CLEAR_FUNC_NAME(TypeName) glib_autoptr_clear_##TypeName
```

not talking it requires split type name, which is not feasible here.

```
#define REMINDER_TYPE_WATCHER (reminder_watcher_get_type ())
G_DECLARE_FINAL_TYPE (ReminderWatcher, reminder_watcher, REMINDER, WATCHER, EReminderWatcher)
```

Thus no, I won't do it here.

messages: Restructure where objects are defined

note.body:
Code-wise probably fine, but commit message needs work:

- it's not only about the `allowed` property, but also the `_shouldShow()` hook;
  there are in fact two changes, one about the visibility of sections, the other
  of the message list as a whole

- the simplification implies a loss of flexibility:
 
  - treats all messages as notifications (→ sessionMode.hasNotifications)
  - removes any flexibility about section visibility (empty → hidden)

    probably fine, as the design no longer calls for tricky visibility rules
    (originally notifications were only shown for the current date, events
    were even shown empty on other dates, etc)
- would be good to check whether extensions implement custom sections,
  we might want to keep the _shouldShow() hook

target_title: messages: Restructure where objects are defined

note.body:
> since there is a file (`messageList.js`) that contains most of the widgets for
messages already, it's a much better place for the `NotificationMessage` and
`NotificationSection`.

With this rationale, I would say that moving the code *out* of the calendar is fine, but it shouldn't be added to messageList. The original design had 4 section types (with the potential for future additions), so there was a split between generic widgetry and consumers (like quickSettings and status/*)

After diving into the grouping MR, I see that there needs to be tighter coupling in the future, so the move makes sense. But the commit message should say so. Having to read through all following commits in the MR plus half of the commits in a follow-up MR in order to really understand the first commit defeats a lot of the benefits of splitting up changes. It certainly slows down review ...

note.body:
> Most of the time in `redraw_view` and `swap_framebuffer` seems to be spent not drawing anything. Instead creating a sync fence and reading back performance counters. I don't know of any way to turn that off, even though it is optional and Mutter can run without it.

```
COGL_DISABLE_GL_EXTENSIONS=GL_ARB_timer_query
```

target_title: gnome-shell uses significant CPU to composite video

note.body:
Thanks @rocketride. Two main problems I can see there:

1. Too much time spent in `drmModeAtomicCommit`. That's probably cursor movement and you can mitigate it using environment `MUTTER_DEBUG_FORCE_KMS_MODE=simple`.

2. Most of the time in `redraw_view` and `swap_framebuffer` seems to be spent not drawing anything. Instead creating a sync fence and reading back performance counters. I don't know of any way to turn that off, even though it is optional and Mutter can run without it.

OK, so this *is* about the time between screen lock and monitor blank.

That's exactly https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-settings-daemon/-/issues/494, so marking as duplicate.

target_title: Proposal: Revising GNOME's Screen Lock Behavior for Desktop Environments
Proposal: Revising GNOME's Screen Lock Behavior for Desktop Environments

note.body:
> I suspect it's already working as you suggest?

No. What I suggested is how Windows and MacOS behave:

1. after a certain time without user activity, the system is considered "idle"
2. desktop will switch to the "lock screen", which is highly customizable, including animated background/slideshow and various widgets and notifications, etc.
3. the "lock screen" is usually shown for quite a long period of time, like 15-60 minutes or so (set by user)
4. then the video output signal is suspended

Right now GNOME behaves like a mobile phone/tablet, and this is not a comfortable UX for desktop/laptop PC.

> That's https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-settings-daemon/-/issues/494. I suspect this is a duplicate.

No. Right now the concept of GNOME's lock screen is just different from Windows and MacOS.

target_title: Alt+tab app switcher is too low contrast

note.body:
This issue is getting bogged down in which specific grey would be best contrast for the app tile. The problem as I can see it is less about contrast than it is that using selected* style here is not sufficient for recognizing which app is highlighted by the switcher.

(*The switcher has it's own special pseudo-class: `:highlighted` which inherits the style of `:selected` tiles.)

Some possible solutions for the status quo:

**1. Use focus styling for the app switcher highlight**

Focus styling being the accent colour ring around an element--this was the initial "solution" folded into !3017--but while it fixed things here there wasn't a consensus (at the time) among the design team about reusing those visuals there, so that folded-in solution was removed.

Admittedly that MR should have probably been disassociated from this issue, but there were some secondary changes that affected things here such as the ring around all icon tiles in HC.

**2. Create a new style for the highlighted pseudoclass**

This might be the way to go here to differentiate the visuals, as well as differentiate from :focus.

**3. Add secondary element to indicate highlight**

Dealing with the style of the tile might all just be working around a problem that could be better solved by adding a small visual cue to the switcher highlight--this idea would need more exploration.

***

Large scale solutions would be to rework alt-tab so it's not a series of app icon tiles but some other presentation of applications--such as window previews--that could be given a different visual treatment entirely but I don't see that as within scope in the near-term.

target_title: Proposal: Revising GNOME's Screen Lock Behavior for Desktop Environments

note.body:
> **Reverse the Order**: Activate the lock screen first, followed by screen blanking after a user-defined delay.

I suspect it's already working as you suggest?

This is what currently happens (on idle - explicit lock is a bit different):
1. after a certain time without user activity, the system is considered "idle"
2. gnome-shell will start fading out the screen to black
3. gnome-shell locks the screen (subject to the `lock-delay` setting, by default immediately)
4. gnome-settings-daemon's power plugin turns off the screen

I don't see how swapping 2+3 makes sense? The screen fading is an indication that the system is about to lock, so the user still has the chance to interrupt by quickly wiggling the pointer (for example when "inactivity" was due to activity that doesn't result in any input events, like reading what's on the screen).

The actual blanking (i.e. turning off screen) happens when the screensaver becomes active, that is when gnome-shell locks the screen.

> Provide user settings to adjust the delay between locking and screen blanking.

That's https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-settings-daemon/-/issues/494. I suspect this is a duplicate.

target_title: RFE - "search as you type" + Enter, sometimes does not wait for search to complete?

note.body:
Another example (that works on a vanilla GNOME system w/o having any non-GNOME app installed) is e.g., trying to launch the terminal but getting the text editor:

1. Search for "te" -> Text Editor is first hit (and selected)
2. Enter "r" *and very quickly*
3. Follow up with pressing Enter -> Text Editor is launched

However, clearly the search did receive the "r" input already and processed it: It's instantly displayed in the search bar without delay, it's just that the "currently selected" application is still the text editor.

Proposed solution:

* Invalidate the "current selected" value whenever a non-Enter event is registered and queue input (can be multiple ones)
* A subsequent Enter will force wait/depend til this value is made available
* Only set "current selected" to a valid value once all input events in the queue are processed.

That way, the correct app will be launched independent of the speed of the device (FWIW, I can reproduce this on an 11th gen i7 in "Performance Mode" on an NVMe SSD with no apps running on F40).

target_title: shell/app: Warn instead of crashing if disposed before stopped

note.body:
> Delete the assertion so gnome-shell doesn't dump core.

I wouldn't want to delete the part of the assertion that the state is at least not in the `SHELL_APP_STATE_RUNNING` state without an explanation how this could happen without there being a shell bug. Otherwise this seems like preemptively papering over unknown bugs to me.

Also we should make sure none of the other shutdown code depends on the emission of the state change change signal to stopped if we want to go with that route. I didn't spot anything obvious but a second pair of eyes would be good.

> Don't log any warnings, since apps continue to function as well as they ever did.

No complaints about that from my side.

target_title: shell/app: Warn instead of crashing if disposed before stopped

note.body:
Maybe the middle ground everyone can agree on is a one line change:
* Delete the assertion so gnome-shell doesn't dump core.
* Don't log any warnings, since apps continue to function as well as they ever did.
